title: 2 Kings Chapter 23 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Kings chapter 23 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Kings Chapter 23 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Kings Chapter 23.

questions.question: Who did the king gather to him at the beginning of his reforms?
options: All the elders of Judah and Jerusalem
All the priests only
The prophets only
The soldiers of Judah
questions.correctAnswer: All the elders of Judah and Jerusalem
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:1 states that the king sent and gathered all the elders of Judah and Jerusalem to him.

questions.question: Where did the king go to read the words of the book of the covenant?
options: House of the LORD
Palace courtyard
City gate
Temple of Baal
questions.correctAnswer: House of the LORD
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:2 mentions that the king went up into the house of the LORD and read the words of the book of the covenant there.

questions.question: What did the king make before the LORD according to 2 Kings 23:3?
options: A covenant to walk after the LORD and keep His commandments
A treaty with surrounding nations
A sacrifice of many animals
A decree to build more altars
questions.correctAnswer: A covenant to walk after the LORD and keep His commandments
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:3 shows the king standing by a pillar and making a covenant before the LORD to walk after Him and keep His commandments.

questions.question: What did the king command Hilkiah the high priest to do with the vessels made for Baal and the host of heaven?
options: Burn them outside Jerusalem in the fields of Kidron
Hide them in the temple
Sell them to merchants
Use them in the temple service
questions.correctAnswer: Burn them outside Jerusalem in the fields of Kidron
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:4 states the king commanded to bring forth all vessels made for Baal and the host of heaven and burn them outside Jerusalem in the fields of Kidron.

questions.question: True or False: Josiah put down the idolatrous priests who burned incense to Baal and the sun.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: According to 2 Kings 23:5, Josiah put down the idolatrous priests who burned incense to Baal, the sun, moon, planets, and the host of heaven.

questions.question: What did Josiah do to the grove from the house of the LORD?
options: Burned it at the brook Kidron and stamped it to powder
Moved it to Bethel
Covered it with stones
Sent it to the king of Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: Burned it at the brook Kidron and stamped it to powder
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:6 records that Josiah brought out the grove and burned it at the brook Kidron, then stamped it to powder.

questions.question: What did Josiah do to the houses of the sodomites near the house of the LORD?
options: Broke them down
Renovated them
Turned them into storehouses
Left them untouched
questions.correctAnswer: Broke them down
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:7 states Josiah broke down the houses of the sodomites near the house of the LORD where women wove hangings for the grove.

questions.question: Which location did Josiah defile to prevent child sacrifice to Molech?
options: Topheth in the valley of the children of Hinnom
The temple of Baal
The high place of Bethel
The city gate of Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Topheth in the valley of the children of Hinnom
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:10 records Josiah defiled Topheth in the valley of the children of Hinnom so no one could make their children pass through fire to Molech.

questions.question: True or False: Josiah kept the passover to the LORD as written in the book of the covenant.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:21 states the king commanded all the people to keep the passover to the LORD as written in the book of the covenant.

questions.question: What did Josiah do with the images and groves in the high places before Jerusalem?
options: Broke images, cut down groves, and filled places with bones of men
Moved them to the temple
Covered them with dirt
Left them intact
questions.correctAnswer: Broke images, cut down groves, and filled places with bones of men
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:14 describes Josiah breaking in pieces images, cutting down groves, and filling their places with human bones.

questions.question: Who was made king after Josiah died?
options: Jehoahaz, his son
Jehoiakim, his son
Manasseh, his father
Pharaohnechoh
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoahaz, his son
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:30 states that after Josiah died, the people made Jehoahaz, his son, king in his father's stead.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'Josiah was twenty and ______ years old when he began to reign.'
options: three
five
six
eight
questions.correctAnswer: eight
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:1 states Josiah was eight years old when he began to reign.

questions.question: What did Pharaohnechoh do to Jehoahaz after he reigned three months?
options: Put him in bands at Riblah in the land of Hamath
Killed him in battle
Made him king of Egypt
Sent him to Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: Put him in bands at Riblah in the land of Hamath
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:33 says Pharaohnechoh put Jehoahaz in bands at Riblah so he could not reign in Jerusalem.

questions.question: True or False: Josiah was the only king who turned to the LORD with all his heart, soul, and might according to the law of Moses.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:25 states that no king before or after Josiah turned to the LORD with all his heart, soul, and might like him.

questions.question: What did Josiah do to the altars made by Ahaz and Manasseh in the house of the LORD?
options: Beat them down and cast their dust into the brook Kidron
Restored and purified them
Moved them to Bethel
Covered them with stones
questions.correctAnswer: Beat them down and cast their dust into the brook Kidron
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:12 says Josiah beat down the altars made by Ahaz and Manasseh and cast the dust into the brook Kidron.

medium.title: 2 Kings Chapter 23 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Kings Chapter 23 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with obedience to God's commandments. Based on 2 Kings 23, what biblical truth would you share about wholehearted obedience?
options: Obedience must come with all the heart and soul, fully committed to God's covenant
Partial obedience is acceptable if the heart is sincere
Obedience is only necessary when it benefits us directly
God values obedience only when others see it
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience must come with all the heart and soul, fully committed to God's covenant
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:3 shows King Josiah making a covenant to walk after the LORD with all his heart and soul, emphasizing total commitment to God's commandments.

questions.question: How does 2 Kings 23 teach us about the importance of removing idols and false influences from our lives?
options: We should actively remove and destroy anything that leads us away from God
Idols can remain if they do not harm others
We should tolerate idols as cultural traditions
Removing idols is optional and depends on personal conviction
questions.correctAnswer: We should actively remove and destroy anything that leads us away from God
questions.explanation: Verses 4-7 illustrate Josiah commanding the removal and burning of vessels for Baal and other idols, showing the need to eliminate false worship to be faithful to God.

questions.question: A family is struggling with spiritual discipline at home. According to 2 Kings 23, what practical step can they take to nurture faith?
options: Regularly gather to read and obey God's word together
Only attend church on special occasions
Rely on children to learn about God at school
Faith should be a private matter without family involvement
questions.correctAnswer: Regularly gather to read and obey God's word together
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:2 describes the king reading the book of the covenant aloud to all the people, including priests and prophets, demonstrating the importance of communal hearing and obedience to God's word.

questions.question: What does 2 Kings 23 teach about spiritual leadership and integrity in the church?
options: Leaders must remove corrupt practices and lead by example
Spiritual leaders can maintain status despite sin
Leadership is based on popularity rather than holiness
Tradition should never be questioned by leaders
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must remove corrupt practices and lead by example
questions.explanation: In verses 5 and 8, Josiah removes idolatrous priests and defiles the high places, demonstrating that spiritual leaders must uphold God's standards and eliminate corruption.

questions.question: How does this chapter encourage believers to persevere through trials related to spiritual renewal?
options: Commit fully to God's law even if others resist or oppose
Avoid change to keep peace with others
Only obey when it is convenient
Ignore spiritual renewal as unnecessary
questions.correctAnswer: Commit fully to God's law even if others resist or oppose
questions.explanation: Josiah's reforms involved breaking down altars and confronting entrenched idolatry (verses 12, 15), showing perseverance and courage in spiritual renewal.

questions.question: What biblical principle about worship is taught by Josiah's actions in 2 Kings 23?
options: True worship requires removing false gods and honoring God alone
Worship styles can include any cultural practices
Idols can be tolerated if they bring peace
God accepts all forms of worship equally
questions.correctAnswer: True worship requires removing false gods and honoring God alone
questions.explanation: Josiah removed idols and destroyed altars dedicated to foreign gods (verses 13-15), emphasizing exclusive worship of the LORD.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with repentance and renewal. Based on 2 Kings 23, what example does King Josiah provide?
options: Repentance involves both covenant renewal and concrete actions to turn from sin
Repentance is only about feeling sorry internally
Renewal can be done without changing actions
Repentance is unnecessary if you are a leader
questions.correctAnswer: Repentance involves both covenant renewal and concrete actions to turn from sin
questions.explanation: Josiah renewed the covenant before the LORD (verse 3) and took concrete steps such as destroying idols and high places (verses 4-20), showing repentance requires both commitment and action.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Kings 23, Josiah celebrated the Passover in a way never before done since the days of the judges.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 22 states that there had not been a Passover like Josiah's since the days of the judges or the kings of Israel and Judah.

questions.question: True or False: Josiah's reforms included tolerating some forms of idolatry to maintain peace in the land.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Josiah completely removed idols, priests of false gods, and destroyed altars and groves without tolerance (verses 4-7, 24).

questions.question: Based on 2 Kings 23, what does Josiah's example teach about the role of the king in guiding the nation spiritually?
options: The king should lead by example in obedience and reform
The king's role is only political and not spiritual
Spiritual matters are left to priests only
The king should avoid confronting sinful practices
questions.correctAnswer: The king should lead by example in obedience and reform
questions.explanation: Josiah personally led the covenant renewal (verse 3) and commanded reforms throughout Judah (verses 4-24), showing leadership in spiritual matters.

questions.question: When a fellow believer asks how to deal with temptation in daily life, what principle from Josiah's reforms in 2 Kings 23 can you share?
options: Remove all occasions and influences that lead to sin
Temptation should be ignored until it passes
Sinful habits can be tolerated if they are common
Avoid accountability when facing temptation
questions.correctAnswer: Remove all occasions and influences that lead to sin
questions.explanation: Josiah removed idols, high places, and false priests (verses 4-8, 24), showing the importance of removing sinful influences to resist temptation.

questions.question: A believer wants to grow in humility and gratitude. What example from Josiah's heart posture in 2 Kings 23 supports this?
options: Josiah turned to the LORD with all his heart, soul, and might, showing complete dependence on God
Josiah relied on his own strength and wisdom
Josiah ignored God's commands when inconvenient
Josiah sought the praise of the people for his reforms
questions.correctAnswer: Josiah turned to the LORD with all his heart, soul, and might, showing complete dependence on God
questions.explanation: Verse 25 praises Josiah for turning to the LORD wholeheartedly, exemplifying humility and gratitude in obedience.

questions.question: How does 2 Kings 23 illustrate the importance of worshiping God with integrity and sincerity?
options: God desires worship that is pure and free from idolatry or hypocrisy
Any form of worship is acceptable if done regularly
Worship is only about outward rituals
Sincerity is enough even if idolatry is present
questions.correctAnswer: God desires worship that is pure and free from idolatry or hypocrisy
questions.explanation: Josiah destroyed idols, defiled false altars, and reinstated true worship (verses 10, 12, 15, 21), emphasizing pure and sincere worship.

questions.question: A believer asks about stewardship and generosity in light of 2 Kings 23. What principle can you share?
options: Faithfulness in obeying God's commands leads to blessing and responsible stewardship
Giving is optional and unrelated to obedience
Stewardship is only about money, not obedience
Generosity is only for the wealthy
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfulness in obeying God's commands leads to blessing and responsible stewardship
questions.explanation: Josiah’s wholehearted obedience (verse 3) and reforms show faithfulness to God's covenant, which includes stewardship of what God entrusts to us.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Josiah's reforms included burning the horses and chariots that were dedicated to the ____.
options: sun
moon
Baal
Molech
questions.correctAnswer: sun
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:11 states Josiah took away the horses given to the sun and burned the chariots of the sun.

hard.title: 2 Kings Chapter 23 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Kings Chapter 23.

questions.question: In 2 Kings 23, what significant covenant action did King Josiah perform before the LORD, reflecting a renewal similar to earlier Mosaic covenants?
options: He tore down the high places and idols
He stood by a pillar and made a covenant to walk after the LORD with all his heart and soul
He sent prophets to proclaim a new law
He built a new altar in Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: He stood by a pillar and made a covenant to walk after the LORD with all his heart and soul
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:3 describes Josiah standing by a pillar and making a covenant before the LORD to keep His commandments with all his heart and soul, echoing the Mosaic covenant renewal themes seen in Deuteronomy.

questions.question: Which ancient Near Eastern religious practice did Josiah explicitly seek to abolish by defiling Topheth in the Valley of Hinnom?
options: Child sacrifice to Molech
Worship of Baal in high places
Divination by familiar spirits
Sun worship through horse offerings
questions.correctAnswer: Child sacrifice to Molech
questions.explanation: In 2 Kings 23:10, Josiah defiled Topheth to prevent anyone from passing their children through fire to Molech, a practice condemned throughout the Hebrew Bible (e.g., Leviticus 18:21).

questions.question: The burning of the chariots of the sun and removal of horses near the temple reflects Josiah's rejection of which foreign deity's cult?
options: Baal
Molech
The sun god
Chemosh
questions.correctAnswer: The sun god
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:11 records Josiah taking away horses given to the sun and burning the sun chariots, symbolizing the rejection of sun worship, a common Near Eastern cult practice.

questions.question: Josiah's reforms included destroying the high places built by Solomon for foreign gods. Which gods were specifically mentioned?
options: Ashtoreth, Chemosh, and Milcom
Baal, Molech, and Dagon
Astarte, Bel, and Nisroch
Marduk, Tammuz, and Ishtar
questions.correctAnswer: Ashtoreth, Chemosh, and Milcom
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:13 notes the high places built by Solomon for Ashtoreth (Zidonians), Chemosh (Moabites), and Milcom (Ammonites), highlighting Josiah's effort to purge syncretistic worship.

questions.question: How does Josiah's extensive religious reform in 2 Kings 23 relate typologically to the reforms of King Hezekiah earlier in Judah's history?
options: Both kings destroyed idols and centralized worship in Jerusalem
Hezekiah focused only on political reform, Josiah on religious
Hezekiah's reforms were more comprehensive than Josiah's
Josiah followed the Assyrian religious model unlike Hezekiah
questions.correctAnswer: Both kings destroyed idols and centralized worship in Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Josiah's reforms parallel Hezekiah's (2 Kings 18) in destroying idols and abolishing high places, emphasizing centralized worship in Jerusalem, a key Deuteronomic theme.

questions.question: The discovery and reading of the 'book of the covenant' played a pivotal role in Josiah's reforms. What is the probable identity of this 'book' based on intertextual biblical evidence?
options: A copy of the Pentateuch or Deuteronomy
A prophetic scroll from Isaiah
A collection of Psalms
The Book of Judges
questions.correctAnswer: A copy of the Pentateuch or Deuteronomy
questions.explanation: Scholars generally identify the 'book of the covenant' (2 Kings 23:2) with Deuteronomy or a similar legal text, as Josiah’s reforms align closely with Deuteronomic laws.

questions.question: What does the act of burning bones on the altar at Bethel signify in the context of ancient Israelite religious practice and prophecy fulfillment?
options: Desecration to fulfill a prophetic word
A ritual purification ceremony
A traditional burial custom
An offering to the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Desecration to fulfill a prophetic word
questions.explanation: Josiah burned bones on the altar (2 Kings 23:16, 20) to pollute it, fulfilling the prophecy of a man of God (likely 1 Kings 13), symbolizing judgment on idolatry at Bethel.

questions.question: True or False: Josiah's reforms completely averted the impending judgment and exile pronounced on Judah due to previous kings' sins.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Despite Josiah's wholehearted reforms (2 Kings 23:25), the LORD declares in 23:26-27 that judgment and removal of Judah and Jerusalem will still occur due to Manasseh’s provocations.

questions.question: Which foreign king killed Josiah in battle, and what does this event foreshadow in the geopolitical context of Judah?
options: Pharaohnechoh of Egypt; foreshadows Egypt's dominance over Judah
Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon; foreshadows Babylonian exile
Sennacherib of Assyria; foreshadows Assyrian invasion
Cyrus of Persia; foreshadows Persian restoration
questions.correctAnswer: Pharaohnechoh of Egypt; foreshadows Egypt's dominance over Judah
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:29 states Pharaohnechoh killed Josiah at Megiddo; this marks a shift in power and foreshadows Judah's subjugation to Egypt and later Babylon.

questions.question: What was the significance of Josiah's command to keep the Passover as described in this chapter, especially in light of Israel's history?
options: It was the first Passover ever celebrated in Jerusalem
It was more solemn and comprehensive than any since the days of the judges
It introduced a new festival replacing Passover
It was a private celebration only for the royal family
questions.correctAnswer: It was more solemn and comprehensive than any since the days of the judges
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:22 states that such a Passover had not been held since the days of the judges, indicating Josiah's reform restored covenant faithfulness.

questions.question: How does the removal of idolatrous priests and defiling of high places in 2 Kings 23 reflect the Deuteronomic principle of centralized worship?
options: It enforces worship only in the temple of the LORD in Jerusalem
It encourages local high place worship
It permits multiple altars in different cities
It abolishes the priesthood entirely
questions.correctAnswer: It enforces worship only in the temple of the LORD in Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Josiah's removal of priests and destruction of high places (2 Kings 23:5, 8) aligns with Deuteronomy 12's command to worship solely at the central sanctuary in Jerusalem.

questions.question: Josiah’s destruction of groves and idols and filling their places with human bones can be understood as a form of:
options: Symbolic judgment and desecration of idolatry
An act of funerary reverence
A new type of pagan worship
A ritual to bless the land
questions.correctAnswer: Symbolic judgment and desecration of idolatry
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:14 describes Josiah breaking images, cutting down groves, and filling places with bones, symbolizing judgment against and desecration of idolatrous sites.

questions.question: What does the renaming of Eliakim to Jehoiakim by Pharaohnechoh symbolize in the political and theological context of Judah’s decline?
options: Imposition of foreign authority and loss of independence
A religious reform initiated by Egypt
A sign of divine blessing
A restoration of the Davidic covenant
questions.correctAnswer: Imposition of foreign authority and loss of independence
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:34 shows Pharaohnechoh renaming Eliakim to Jehoiakim, symbolizing Judah’s vassalage and political subjugation under Egypt, reflecting loss of sovereignty.

questions.question: In the literary structure of 2 Kings 23, how does the narrative of Josiah's reforms (verses 1-25) contrast with the account of his death and succession (verses 26-37)?
options: Reforms highlight covenant faithfulness; death and succession highlight political downfall
Both sections emphasize military conquest
Both sections focus on temple construction
Reforms focus on foreign alliances; death focus on spiritual renewal
questions.correctAnswer: Reforms highlight covenant faithfulness; death and succession highlight political downfall
questions.explanation: The chapter contrasts Josiah's religious zeal and covenant renewal (vv.1-25) with his death and the political instability following (vv.26-37), underscoring the limits of reform without political stability.

questions.question: Josiah’s reforms in 2 Kings 23 can be seen as a typological foreshadowing of which New Testament theme?
options: The call to repentance and exclusive worship of God
The establishment of a new temple in Jerusalem
The spreading of the gospel to the Gentiles
The building of a political kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: The call to repentance and exclusive worship of God
questions.explanation: Josiah’s purge of idolatry and covenant renewal (2 Kings 23) typologically anticipates New Testament calls for repentance and exclusive devotion to God (e.g., Acts 3:19).

theological.title: 2 Kings Chapter 23 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Kings Chapter 23 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What covenant did King Josiah make before the LORD according to 2 Kings 23?
options: To walk after the LORD and keep His commandments with all his heart and soul
To build more high places for worship
To ally with Egypt against Assyria
To appoint new priests for Baal worship
questions.correctAnswer: To walk after the LORD and keep His commandments with all his heart and soul
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:3 records Josiah standing by a pillar and making a covenant before the LORD to walk after Him and keep His commandments with all his heart and soul, which reflects God’s call for wholehearted obedience (Deuteronomy 6:5; Joshua 24:15; Jeremiah 32:39; 1 Samuel 12:24).

questions.question: Which items did King Josiah command to be removed and destroyed from the temple of the LORD?
options: Vessels made for Baal, the grove, and the host of heaven
Scrolls of the law that were damaged
Golden idols of Aaron
Sacrificial animals used in pagan rituals
questions.correctAnswer: Vessels made for Baal, the grove, and the host of heaven
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:4 states Josiah commanded the high priest and others to remove vessels made for Baal, the grove, and the host of heaven from the temple and burn them, emphasizing the rejection of idolatry (Exodus 20:3-5; Deuteronomy 7:25-26; Jeremiah 10:3-5; 1 Corinthians 10:14).

questions.question: What did Josiah do to the high places where incense was burned across Judah?
options: He brought out all the priests and defiled and broke down the high places
He sanctified them as new centers of worship
He ignored them to focus on Jerusalem
He gave them to foreign priests
questions.correctAnswer: He brought out all the priests and defiled and broke down the high places
questions.explanation: According to 2 Kings 23:8, Josiah removed the priests from the high places and defiled and destroyed those places, underscoring God’s exclusivity in worship (Deuteronomy 12:2-4; Exodus 34:13; Isaiah 57:13; Hebrews 10:22).

questions.question: What was the significance of Josiah defiling Topheth in the valley of the children of Hinnom?
options: To prevent child sacrifice to Molech
To establish a new sacrificial site
To build a royal palace
To create a marketplace
questions.correctAnswer: To prevent child sacrifice to Molech
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:10 explains Josiah defiled Topheth to stop people from passing their children through fire to Molech, condemning idolatrous and abhorrent practices prohibited by God (Leviticus 18:21; Deuteronomy 12:31; Jeremiah 7:31; Ezekiel 16:20-21).

questions.question: How did Josiah treat the horses and chariots dedicated to the sun?
options: He took them away and burned the chariots of the sun with fire
He used them in battle against Egypt
He gave them to the priests of the LORD
He preserved them as historical artifacts
questions.correctAnswer: He took them away and burned the chariots of the sun with fire
questions.explanation: Per 2 Kings 23:11, Josiah removed the horses and burned the chariots dedicated to the sun, demonstrating rejection of pagan sun worship (Deuteronomy 4:19; 2 Kings 21:3; Isaiah 45:7; Colossians 2:8-10).

questions.question: What did Josiah do with the altar and high place at Bethel, which Jeroboam built?
options: He broke down the altar, burned the high place, stamped it to powder, and burned the grove
He renovated it for temple worship
He left it untouched out of respect
He dedicated it to the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: He broke down the altar, burned the high place, stamped it to powder, and burned the grove
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:15 records Josiah destroying the altar and high place at Bethel, indicating a rejection of syncretistic worship established by Jeroboam (Exodus 20:5; Deuteronomy 12:4; 1 Kings 12:28-30; Revelation 2:14).

questions.question: What was Josiah's attitude toward the bones found on the altar at Bethel, and what did he do with them?
options: He burned the bones on the altar, thereby polluting it according to the word of the LORD
He buried the bones respectfully nearby
He placed the bones in the temple treasury
He left the bones untouched
questions.correctAnswer: He burned the bones on the altar, thereby polluting it according to the word of the LORD
questions.explanation: According to 2 Kings 23:16, Josiah burned the bones on the altar to defile it, fulfilling prophecy and showing zeal for purifying worship (Numbers 19:11-13; Ezekiel 36:25; Leviticus 20:27; Psalm 139:8).

questions.question: What distinguished Josiah's reign in terms of his devotion to God compared to previous kings?
options: He turned to the LORD with all his heart, soul, and might, unlike any king before or after him
He maintained the status quo of worship practices
He was the most warlike king of Judah
He allied with pagan nations for peace
questions.correctAnswer: He turned to the LORD with all his heart, soul, and might, unlike any king before or after him
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:25 states that no king before or after Josiah turned to the LORD with such wholehearted devotion, illustrating the biblical ideal of covenant faithfulness (Deuteronomy 6:5; 1 Kings 8:61; Psalm 86:11; Matthew 22:37).

questions.question: Despite Josiah’s reforms, what did the LORD declare would still happen to Judah and Jerusalem?
options: Judah and Jerusalem would be removed and cast off because of past provocations
They would experience peace and prosperity forever
They would be exalted above all nations
They would be spared from all judgment
questions.correctAnswer: Judah and Jerusalem would be removed and cast off because of past provocations
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:26-27 reveals God's judgment upon Judah and Jerusalem despite Josiah's reforms, due to prior sins, emphasizing God's justice and holiness (Jeremiah 25:8-11; Ezekiel 9:6; Romans 1:18; Hebrews 10:30).

questions.question: Who succeeded Josiah as king and how long did he reign according to 2 Kings 23?
options: Jehoahaz, who reigned three months
Jehoiakim, who reigned thirty years
Manasseh, who reigned fifty-five years
Amon, who reigned two years
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoahaz, who reigned three months
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:30-31 specifies that Jehoahaz, Josiah’s son, reigned only three months, showing the instability after Josiah’s death (1 Kings 15:8; 2 Chronicles 21:20; Jeremiah 22:10-12; Acts 13:22).

questions.question: What was Pharaohnechoh’s role in the reign of Jehoahaz and Jehoiakim?
options: He deposed Jehoahaz, imprisoned him, and installed Jehoiakim as king
He allied with Jehoahaz against Assyria
He ignored Judah’s kings entirely
He destroyed Jerusalem immediately
questions.correctAnswer: He deposed Jehoahaz, imprisoned him, and installed Jehoiakim as king
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:33-34 narrates Pharaohnechoh putting Jehoahaz in chains and making Eliakim (Jehoiakim) king, illustrating foreign political control over Judah (Jeremiah 22:10-12; 2 Chronicles 36:4-5; Daniel 2:37-39; Isaiah 10:5-6).

questions.question: What action did Josiah command all the people to observe, and how was it significant?
options: Keep the Passover to the LORD as written in the book of the covenant
Celebrate the New Year festival with foreign customs
Offer sacrifices to Baal for prosperity
Establish a new festival for the king’s birthday
questions.correctAnswer: Keep the Passover to the LORD as written in the book of the covenant
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:21-22 records Josiah commanding the people to celebrate Passover according to the covenant law, marking a revival of proper worship and remembering God’s deliverance (Exodus 12:14; Leviticus 23:5; Joshua 5:10-11; Luke 22:15-16).

questions.question: How did Josiah deal with workers of familiar spirits, wizards, images, idols, and other abominations in Judah and Jerusalem?
options: He put them away to perform the words of the law found in the book discovered by Hilkiah
He incorporated them into temple worship
He ignored their presence
He appointed them as royal advisors
questions.correctAnswer: He put them away to perform the words of the law found in the book discovered by Hilkiah
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:24 indicates Josiah removed occult workers and idols to obey the law, demonstrating the biblical rejection of occult and idolatry (Deuteronomy 18:10-12; Leviticus 19:31; Galatians 5:19-21; Colossians 2:8).

questions.question: In 2 Kings 23, what does Josiah's reform reveal about God's desire for His people?
options: God desires exclusive worship and covenant obedience with heart and soul
God is indifferent to worship practices
God accepts all religious syncretism
God prefers political alliances over holiness
questions.correctAnswer: God desires exclusive worship and covenant obedience with heart and soul
questions.explanation: Josiah’s reforms (2 Kings 23) underscore God’s covenantal demand for exclusive, wholehearted worship (Exodus 20:3; Deuteronomy 6:5; Isaiah 1:11-17; John 4:23-24).

questions.question: What theological truth is shown by Josiah’s inability to prevent the coming judgment on Judah despite his reforms?
options: God’s justice requires judgment for persistent corporate sin despite individual repentance
Human efforts alone can avert divine judgment without repentance
God overlooks national sins for the sake of a few righteous individuals
God’s promises are unconditional regardless of behavior
questions.correctAnswer: God’s justice requires judgment for persistent corporate sin despite individual repentance
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 23:26-27 shows that despite Josiah’s faithfulness, God’s wrath remained due to prior provocations, affirming divine justice and the corporate nature of covenant consequences (Ezekiel 18:20; Romans 5:12; Hebrews 10:26-31; 2 Chronicles 36:16).
